name: Indo-European (> Italic)
macroareas: Africa, Australia, Eurasia, North America, Papunesia, South America
2_comment: In parts of Latin America siempre ‘always’ can, like the French toujours, mean ‘still’

name: Indo-European (> Indo-Iranian)
macroareas: Africa, Australia, Eurasia, North America, Papunesia, South America
1_comment: no special description, first meaning is now

name: Hmong-Mien
1_comment: no special description, sometimes glossed as progr

name: Nakh-Daghestanian
1_diachronic_sources: stay (see also Maisak's paper on Andi)
2_comment: there are also particles helelig, gilani (gila 'now' plus -ni 'also, even') and mad

name: Mongolic-Khitan
1_comment: the particle l somehow contributes the meaning of still

name: Chukotko-Kamchatkan
source_type: grammar, Bible, small glossed corpus, expert

name: Kartvelian
1_comment: no special description; there is also a particle "mainc" meaning "still = nevertheless"

name: Abkhaz-Adyge
source_type: grammar, Bible, small glossed corpus, expert, speaker

name: Yukaghir
1_comment: the meanings "still" and "more" can be distinguished by means of the linear position of the particle

name: Hurro-Urartian
1_comment: no special description; It is unclear how zugan should be translated, but it almost certainly functions as an adverb in this context

name: Koreanic
1_comment: no special description, see ex. 289, 166 for not yet
2_comment: these suffixes occur mostly with onomatopoetic roots

name: Nivkh
1_comment: no special description, see ex. 937 for not yet
